title: Encrypt the communication using a server certificate
content:
This section describes the encryption and obfuscation of the communication using a server certificate.

Replace the OO Workflow Designer TLS server certificate

You can use a certificate signed by a well-known certificate authority or a custom server certificate from a local certificate authority.

Replace the parameters between brackets < > to match the location of the key.store file and other details on your computer.

The following procedure uses the keytool utility located in <installation dir>/java/bin/keytool.
  1. Stop OO Workflow Designer and back up the original key.store file, located in <installation dir>/designer/var/security.
  2. Open a command line in <installation dir>/designer/var/security.
  3. Delete the existing server certificate from the OO Workflow Designer key.store file, using the following command: 
    keytool -delete -alias tomcat -keystore key.store -storepass changeit

    If you already have a certificate with a .pfx or .p12 extension go to the next step. If not, you need to export the certificate with a private key into PKCS12 format (.pfx, .p12). For example, if the certificate format is PEM:

    >openssl pkcs12 –export –in <cert.pem> -inkey <.key> -out <certificate name>.p12 –name <name>

    If the certificate format is DER, add the –inform DER parameter after PKCS12. For example:

    >openssl pkcs12 –inform DER –export –in <cert.pem> -inkey <.key> -out <certificate name>.p12 –name <name>
    You must use your CA to generate the PKCS12 format certificate. As this step may vary according to CA vendor and policy, contact your CA for a detailed explanation of the certificate generation process.
    Make a note of the password you provide. You will need this password for the private key when you input the KeyStore passphrase later in this procedure. Make sure to choose a strong password.
  4. List the alias for your certificate’s alias, using the following command: 
    keytool -list -keystore <certificate_name> -v -storetype PKCS12

    The certificate alias is displayed and should be provided in the next command.

    In the example below, it is the fourth line from the bottom.

  5. Import the PKCS12 format server certificate to the OO Workflow Designer key.store file using the following command: 
    keytool -importkeystore -srckeystore <PKCS12 format certificate path> -destkeystore key.store -srcstoretype pkcs12 -deststoretype JKS -alias <cert alias> -destalias tomcat
    The alias should be tomcat unless it is also changed in the server.xml file.
  6. If the imported server certificate has a different password from the original server certificate, it's important to change the keyPass password. It's also recommended to change the default “changeit” password in the automatically generated KeyStore in the OO Workflow Designer server.
  7. Start OO Workflow Designer.

Import a CA root certificate to the OO Workflow Designer TrustStore

If you are using a custom root certificate for OO Workflow Designer, you will need to import the trusted root certificate authority (CA) to the client.truststore. If you are using a well-known root CA (like Verisign) you do not have to perform the following procedure because the certificate will already be in the client.truststore file.

By default, OO Workflow Designer supports all self-signed certificates. However, in a production environment, it's recommended to change this default to a custom CA or a well-known CA for security reasons.

Replace the parameters between brackets < >.

The following procedure uses the keytool utility located in <installation dir>/java/bin/keytool.
  1. Stop OO Workflow Designer and back up the original client.truststore file, located in <installation dir>/designer/var/security/client.truststore.
  2. Import the trusted root certificate authority (CA) to the OO Workflow Designer client.truststore file if it doesn't already exist in the CA list (by default, all the well-known CAs are there). 
    keytool -importcert -alias <any_alias> -keystore <path to the client.truststore> -file <certificate_name.cer> -storepass <changeit>
  3. Start OO Workflow Designer.

Change the KeyStore, TrustStore, and server certificate passwords in the OO Workflow Designer configuration

  1. Make sure that OO Workflow Designer is running.
    Before doing this step, make sure that there are encrypted passwords.
  2. Stop the OO Workflow Designer service.
  3. Change the KeyStore, TrustStore, and server certificate password using keytool. Use the following keytool command to change the KeyStore password: 
    keytool -storepasswd -keystore <installation_folder>/designer/var/security/key.store
    Use the following keytool command to change the server certificate private key entry password: 
    keytool –keypasswd -alias tomcat -keystore <installation_folder>/designer/var/security/key.store

    Use the following keytool command to change the TrustStore password:

    keytool -storepasswd -keystore <installation_folder>/designer/var/security/client.truststore
  4. Change the passwords also in the server.xml file located in <installation dir>/designer/tomcat/conf/server.xml.
    1. Locate the certificate portion of the HTTPS connector. For example: 
      truststoreFile="C:/Program Files/Micro Focus/Operations Orchestration/designer/var/security/client.truststore" truststorePassword="changeit" truststoreType="JKS">
<Certificate certificateKeyAlias="tomcat" certificateKeyPassword="changeit" certificateKeystoreFile="C:/Program Files/Micro Focus/Operations Orchestration/designer/var/security/key.store" certificateKeystorePassword="changeit" certificateKeystoreType="JKS"/>

      Change the required password.

      • certificatekeyPassword - the password used to access the server certificate private key from the specified key.store file. The default value is "changeit".
      • certificatekeystorePassword - the password used to access the specified key.store file. The default value is the value of the certificatekeyPassword attribute.
      It's recommended not to use the same password as the certificatekeyPassword and to use a strong password.
      • truststorePassword - the password to access the TrustStore (that includes all of the trusted CAs). The default is the value of the javax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword system property. If that property is null, no TrustStore password will be configured. If an invalid TrustStore password is specified, a warning will be logged and an attempt will be made to access the TrustStore without a password, which will skip validation of the TrustStore contents.
    2. Save the file.
  5. Edit the designer-wrapper.conf file located in <installation dir> designer\conf\ and replace the password of the TrustStore with a new password in encrypted or obfuscated form. Examples: 
    wrapper.java.additional.<x>=-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword={ENCRYPTED}<encrypted_password>
    wrapper.java.additional.<x>=-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword={OBFUSCATED}<obfuscated_password>
  6. Start the OO Workflow Designer service.

Encrypt passwords

You can encrypt a password using the encrypt-password script located in <installation_folder>/designer/bin.

It's recommended to use encryption.

After using the encrypt-password script, clear the command history. This is because, on a Linux OS, the password parameter will be stored in cleartext under /$USER/.bash_history and accessible by the history command.

To encrypt passwords:

  1. Locate the encrypt-password script, in <installation_folder>/designer/bin.
  2. Run the script with the -e -p <password> option, where password is the password you want to encrypt.
You can either use -p as the flag to encrypt the password or --password.

The encrypted password should appear as follows:

{ENCRYPTED}<some_chars>.

Creating a prompt for a password

It's recommended to run the encrypt-password script without providing the –p argument. For example:

This will create a prompt for the hidden password inputs.

Remove the RC4 cipher from the SSL-supported ciphers

The remote host supports the use of the RC4 cipher. This cipher is flawed in its generation of a pseudo-random stream of bytes so that a wide variety of small biases are introduced into the stream, decreasing its randomness.

If plain text is repeatedly encrypted (for example, HTTP cookies), and an attacker can obtain many (i.e., tens of millions of) cipher texts, the attacker may be able to derive the plain text.

Disable the RC4 cipher on the JRE level (starting with Java 7):

  1. Open the <installation_dir>/java/bin/lib/security/java.security file.
  2. Disable the RC4 cipher by removing the comments and changing the parameters according to the example below: 
    jdk.certpath.disabledAlgorithms=RC4, MD2, RSA keySize < 1024
    jdk.tls.disabledAlgorithms=RC4, MD5, DSA, RSA keySize < 1024
  3. Restart the OO Workflow Designer server.

For more information, see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18589761/restict-cipher-suites-on-jre-level.

Change or disable the HTTP or HTTPS ports

The server.xml file under [OO_HOME]/designer/tomcat/conf contains two elements named <Connector> under the element <Service>. These connectors define or enable the ports that the server is listening on. Each connector configuration is defined through its attributes. The first connector defines a regular HTTP connector and the second defines an HTTPS connector.

By default, the connectors look as follows.

HTTP connector:

<Connector URIEncoding="UTF-8" compression="on" connectionTimeout="20000" port="8080" protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol" redirectPort="8443"/>

HTTPS connector:

<Connector SSLEnabled="true" URIEncoding="UTF-8" allowTrace="false" compression="on" maxSwallowSize="-1" maxThreads="200" port="8095" protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol" scheme="https" secure="true" server="OODESIGNER">
    <SSLHostConfig ciphers="TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_AES_128_CCM_SHA256,TLS_AES_128_CCM_8_SHA256,TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256" enabledProtocols="TLSv1.3" protocols="TLSv1.3,TLSv1.2" truststoreFile="C:/Program Files/Micro Focus/Operations Orchestration/designer/var/security/client.truststore" truststorePassword="changeit" truststoreType="JKS">
        <Certificate certificateKeyAlias="tomcat" certificateKeyPassword="changeit" certificateKeystoreFile="C:/Program Files/Micro Focus/Operations Orchestration/designer/var/security/key.store" certificateKeystorePassword="changeit" certificateKeystoreType="JKS"/>
    </SSLHostConfig>
</Connector>

By default, both are enabled.

If you change or disable one of the Designerl ports in the server.xml file, you must also update the designer-wrapper.conf file and each RAS-wrapper.conf file to point to the Designer URL with the updated port. Otherwise, all your flows will fail when run from Designer. Also, make sure to check the load balancer configurations.

Change port values

To change the values of one of the ports:

  1. Edit the server.xml file located in <installation_dir>/designer/tomcat/conf/server.xml.

  2. Locate the HTTP or HTTPS connector, and adjust the port value in the line.

    If you are keeping both HTTP and HTTPS active and you want to change the HTTPS port, you will need to change the redirectPort value for the HTTP connector and the port value for the HTTPS connector.

  3. Save the file.
  4. Restart OO Workflow Designer.

Disable the HTTP port

For security reasons, you might want to disable the HTTP port so that the only communication channel will be on TLS and encrypted.

  1. Edit the server.xml file located in <installation_dir>/designer/tomcat/conf/server.xml.
  2. Locate the HTTP connector, and delete or comment out the line.

  3. Import the trusted root certificate authority (CA) to the Designer client.truststore file, if it doesn't already exist in the CA list:

    keytool -importcert -alias <any_alias> -keystore <path to the client.truststore> -file <certificate_name.cer> -storepass <changeit>

    If you are using a well-known root CA (like Verisign) you do not have to perform this step, because the certificate will already be in the client.truststore file.

  4. Save the file.
  5. Restart OO Workflow Designer.

It's also possible to disable the HTTP port during installation.

Configure the secured properties

When OO Workflow Designer was installed, decisions were made that may affect security. When the LW-SSO initialization string was set, a decision was made about whether to keep the HTTP port open, and a proxy may have been configured. If you need to change these decisions after installation, you can adjust the parameters in the secured.properties file. For example, an administrator might decide to harden the configuration and close the HTTP port. In this case, you need to set the secure flag for the CSRF cookie.

In the secured.properties file, you can configure the size limit of content packs that can be uploaded to OO Workflow Designer. The default size limit is 200 MB (the exact size limit is 209715200 bytes). However, you may want to adjust this to protect against DOS (Denial of Service). You can also configure the number of content packs that can be uploaded in parallel, and the number of content packs that can be created in parallel.

Set SSL configuration properties

Setting SSL configuration properties affects secured communication with external applications or services such as Git server and OO Workflow Designer.

Supporting self-signed certificates

Self-signed certificates are user-generated certificates that have not been signed by a well-known CA and are, therefore, not guaranteed to be authentic. While self-signed certificates can be useful for some testing scenarios, they are not suitable for production use.

To allow the OO Workflow Designer server to accept work with self-signed certificates, the ssl.support-self-signed property must be enabled (in the designer-wrapper file). This property is enabled by default.

Hostname verification

Hostname verification ensures that both the hostname in the URL and the hostname sent back by the server in the digital certificate match. By default, hostname verification is enabled, and we recommend enabling this in a production environment to prevent man-in-the-middle attacks. To disable this verification, you can set the ssl.verifyHostname property to false.

Troubleshoot the HTTPS connector

If the server doesn’t start, open the wrapper.log file and look for an error in ProtocolHandler ["http-nio-8443"]. This can happen when Tomcat is initializing or starting the connector. There are many variations but the error message can provide information.

All the HTTPS connector parameters are in the Tomcat configuration file located at <installation>designer\tomcat\conf\server.xml. Open the file and scroll to the end, until you see the HTTPS connector:

<Connector SSLEnabled="true" URIEncoding="UTF-8" allowTrace="false" compression="on" maxSwallowSize="-1" maxThreads="200" port="8095" protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol" scheme="https" secure="true" server="OODESIGNER">
    <SSLHostConfig ciphers="TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_AES_128_CCM_SHA256,TLS_AES_128_CCM_8_SHA256,TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256" enabledProtocols="TLSv1.3" protocols="TLSv1.3,TLSv1.2" truststoreFile="C:/Program Files/Micro Focus/Operations Orchestration/designer/var/security/client.truststore" truststorePassword="changeit" truststoreType="JKS">
        <Certificate certificateKeyAlias="tomcat" certificateKeyPassword="changeit" certificateKeystoreFile="C:/Program Files/Micro Focus/Operations Orchestration/designer/var/security/key.store" certificateKeystorePassword="changeit" certificateKeystoreType="JKS"/>
    </SSLHostConfig>
</Connector>

Check if there is any mismatch in the parameters, by comparing them to the parameters you entered in the previous steps.

Troubleshoot multiple deployment requests

Sending multiple deployment requests can block and even slow down the whole system. In the secured.properties file, located in <installation_dir>/designer/var/security/, the value of the max.parallel.cp.creation key limits the number of simultaneous CP deployments to Designer (the key refers only to parallel CP creation; for CP deployments to Designer there is a different parameter: max.parallel.cp.upload with the default value =50). The default is 30. If users get errors that the limit was reached, the administrator should consider increasing this value.

An attacker might also use this behavior, together with automated tools, to create a DoS attack on the system and prevent legitimate users from using it. In such a case, the administrator should identify the malicious IP address/domain and block it.

  1. Open the secured.properties file, located in <installation_dir>/designer/var/security/.
  2. If you need to close the HTTP port, make sure that the is.secured.cookie property is activated, as follows. 
    is.secured.cookie=true

    Setting the is.secured.cookie property to true adds a secured attribute to the CSRF cookie. This is the default when OO Workflow Designer is installed with no HTTP connection. However, if OO Workflow Designer was installed with an HTTP connection and you want to harden the installation later, you can change this property to true.

    This should be set to true only when HTTP is disabled. Setting it to true when HTTP is enabled will prevent the users from working in HTTP.

    To close the HTTP port, you also need to complete the other steps described in "Disable the HTTP port" under "Change and disable the HTTP/HTTPS ports" topic.

  3. To verify that the LW-SSO initialization string is encrypted, enter the encryption string in the lwsso.initString property. This string must be at least 12 characters long and must be the same LW-SSO initialization string used by the embedding application.
  4. To adjust the number of content packs that can be created in parallel across the system (for all users), update the value of the max.parallel.cp.creation property. (The default is 30).
  5. To adjust the number of content packs that can be uploaded to OO Workflow Designer in parallel, update the value of the max.parallel.cp.upload property. (The default is 50).
  6. To adjust the size limit of content packs that can be uploaded to OO Workflow Designer, update the value of the upload.max.fileSize.limit property.
  7. Restart OO Workflow Designer.
    1. Open the designer.wrapper.conf file, located under <installation dir>/conf/.
    2. Add the ssl.support-self-signed and the ssl.verifyHostName properties to the designer.wrapper.conf file.
    3. If you set the ssl.support-self-signed value to true the OO Workflow Designer server will allow work with self-signed certificates.
    4. If you set the ssl.verifyHostName value to false, this disables the verification of the hostname matching between the URL and the certificate.
    5. Restart OO Workflow Designer.
